awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: CEDAR: Causal Relationships of Ion-neutral Coupling Processes at Mid-latitudes
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this study is to advance our understanding of the coupling and causal links between high-latitude forcing of the thermosphere and mid-latitude plasma density structuring during both quiet and storm times. The study will also characterize the relative importance of spatial/temporal variation at the high-latitude boundary between the magnetosphere and ionosphere in generating observed variability in the mid-latitudes. The knowledge gained will impact the development of future models by identifying any missing physics in the models as well as the spatial/temporal resolutions required to capture relevant processes. Improving modeling is critical to enabling space weather forecasting capabilities, and will enhance the infrastructure for research and education.	
	This project will address two fundamental questions: 1) What is the cause/effect relationship between high-latitude forcing on the neutral winds and the response of electron densities at mid-latitudes, especially during geomagnetic storm conditions? 2) What is the relationship between spatial/temporal variability within the high-latitude drivers and the variability observed within the mid-latitude neutral winds and ionospheric structure? Observations of mid-latitude thermospheric winds and temperatures made by the North American Thermosphere-Ionosphere Observation Network (NATION) of Fabry-Perot interferometers (FPI) will be coupled with time-dependent 3D electron density estimates from the Ionospheric Data Assimilation Four Dimensional (IDA4D) assimilative model. The source of the dynamics observed in the thermospheric neutral winds and electron density will be investigated through exercising an inversion algorithm (Estimating Model Parameters from Ionospheric Reverse Engineering; EMPIRE) developed to estimate the ionospheric drivers from three-dimensional, time-evolving distributions of ionospheric electron densities. The first-principles Global Ionosphere Thermosphere Model (GITM) will also be used to elucidate the underlying physics responsible for the coupling. This study will contribute to the education and training of graduate students at the University of Illinois and the University of Michigan.

por.por_cntn:
The atmosphere of the Earth extends up to altitudes where satellites orbit. The top layer of the atmosphere, the thermosphere, starts around 60 miles above the surface of the Earth and extends to about 350 miles altitude. The International Space Station orbits at around 250 miles altitude, for reference. In this region of the atmosphere, there are winds and pressures, just like down in the lower atmosphere where we live.  The winds and pressures are very different, though. Processes like the northern lights and other things having to do with the sun's interaction with our near-Earth space environment cause there to be very strong winds in the upper atmosphere.  For example, winds can reach speeds up to about 1,500 MPH, although they are more commonly around 400 MPH. This grant explored the winds in the upper atmosphere using both measurements of the winds and models that gave predictions of the winds.  It is actually quite difficult to measure the winds in the upper atmosphere, since there are no satellites in orbit that provide these measurements.  The most commonly used method, and the one that we used in this grant, is to look at the night-glow of the atmosphere and measure the doppler shift of that glow.  Because the upper atmosphere has a bunch of ions and electrons in it, it glows weakly (it is both a bit green at around 60 miles high and a bit red at around 160 miles high). The exact color is known very precisely, and so instruments can measure the shift of the light away from the expected color to determine the speed of the wind. This was done at a bunch of locations around the central-eastern part of the United States, and the measurements were used to look at the behaviour of the atmosphere.  Models were also used to explore how the upper atmosphere behaves.  Interestingly, when the data and models were compared, the modeled winds were way too strong. It was found that there was a problem with the viscosity term in the model, which describes how tighly the winds are coupled between the lower and upper atmosphere.  In the model, the viscosity was too low, so the winds were allowed to blow very strongly, while in reality, the winds are most strongly tied to the lower atmosphere.  In another study comparing the modeling results to the data, it was found that if you remove the average day-to-day pattern in the wind and only look at the variability on top of that (can think of this as the "weather"), the model struggled to capture this variability. When the correlation of the weather over different length-scales was investigated (for example, the weather between Detroit and Chicago is pretty strongly similar, but the weather between Detroit and Los Angles is not similar at all), it was found that the correlation lengths in the model was quite different than in the data.  We need to figure out why the model and the data disagree!
